title: Fall Talent Connect Career Fair
description:
Talent Connect is Northeastern University’s biannual, university-wide recruiting event. It enables employers to speak directly with students across all position types (Full Time/Part Time, Internship, and Co-op).

 

The Talent Connect career fairs allow for learning more about each other – the employers’ businesses and career opportunities, and the students’ interests and qualifications. Following these sessions, employers have the ability to identify and interview appropriate students towards the goal of meeting their recruitment needs.

 

Talent Connect is held over three days, featuring both on-campus and virtual sessions.

title: Guest Workshop: Teaching with Writing in an AI-Infused World
description:
Join Teaching Professor Crissy McMartin-Miller to explore challenges and opportunities to teaching with writing in the age of the AI. 

 

GenAI tools have challenged traditional writing assignments, yet writing remains an important process for thinking. Join Crissy McMartin-Miller, Teaching Professor, to explore why it is still valuable to learn and teach writing skills. Topics will include designing assignments that account for AI and assignment-specific AI guidelines, and incorporating AI activities into class. This workshop centers around humanizing the writing process and valuing students’ writing voice.

 

This session is only open to Northeastern University students, staff and educators. Please use your Northeastern email when registering.

Accommodations

 

CATLR is committed to providing universal access to all of our events. For accommodations (e.g., sign language interpreters, alternative formats), please contact CATLR (catlr@northeastern.edu; +1-617-373-3157) as soon as possible. Advance notice is necessary to arrange for some accessibility needs.

title: Synthesizing Sources in Academic Writing
description:
Synthesizing sources is an important skill in academic writing. It means bringing together ideas, evidence, and arguments from multiple texts to create a coherent discussion or an argument. It is different from simply summarizing one source after another; instead, it involves connecting, comparing, and contrasting sources to show relationships in building your own argument.

In this workshop, you will learn how to synthesize sources and why it is important in academic writing. We will also examine various synthesis matrices to build your source materials and understand the process of synthesis through examples.

 

Register here!

title: Reckonings Community Network Series: "Re-Mix, Re-Map, Re-Imagine: Activism in Boston Chinatown"
description:
How can we engage with the history of activism and make connections to a more just future? In this workshop, designed and led by Lani Asunción and Joanna Tam,  Reckonings’ Hidden Histories artists-in-residence, we will activate the language found in the printed materials published and used by grassroots organizations in Boston Chinatown, currently housed at the Northeastern University Archives and Special Collections, through creative mapping and collective imagination. 

 

The gathering is part of the Reckonings Community Network Series.


Please register here.

title: Augmenting Talent from Within: AI, Data Literacy, and Intrapreneurial Innovation
description:
AI’s greatest potential isn’t in replacing people: it’s in amplifying human capability.

This session looks at concrete ways organizations are using AI and data to improve decision-making, build skills across teams, and create new opportunities for innovation.

Tom Davenport, a leading authority on how AI changes human work, will set the stage with insights from his research.

Dan Koloski will share examples of how managers translate AI and data literacy into real workplace practices.

Chris Torina will outline how structured intrapreneurship programs turn employee ideas into business results.

What You’ll Learn

How AI extends, rather than replaces, what people can do and what that means for leadership mindsetsHow middle managers are turning AI and data literacy into day-to-day advancesHow intrapreneurship programs channel employee initiatives into measurable impactQuestions We’ll Explore

How is AI changing the way leaders think about human capability and decision-making? What role do middle managers play in turning AI and data literacy into everyday results? How can organizations structure intrapreneurship so employee ideas become measurable business outcomes? What connections tie these approaches together, and what questions matter most to your organization right now?

This event delivers both high-level perspective and practical cases, giving you clear examples of how organizations are approaching AI and data today.

‍

title: Applied and Interdisciplinary Mathematics (AIM) Seminar
description:
Date:  Thursday, October 16, 2025
Time: 2:00 pm
Location:  Seminar room EXP-701A 

Speaker: Willie Harrison (Brigham Young University)
Title:  Applications of Vector Spaces in Wiretap Code Constructions

Abstract:  Physical-layer security seeks to achieve secure throughput by exploiting the statistics of the noisy transmission channel to an eavesdropper.  In practice, this requires knowledge of the environment coupled with clever application of wiretap codes.  These codes are one-to-many mappings, where single messages are mapped to any of several codewords at random.  The sets of codewords that are assigned to a single message are cosets of a vector space.  This talk presents techniques for optimizing the design of the vector space (and, consequently, the cosets) for best-possible wiretap codes.  We show that for small parameters, the best codes tend to be old codes.

Biography:    Dr. Willie Harrison received his BS/MS degrees from Utah State University in 2007, and his PhD from the Georgia Institute of Technology in 2012.  He was an assistant professor at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs from 2012-2017, and he joined the faculty in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Brigham Young University in the fall of 2017, where he is currently an Associate Professor.  His research interests are in physical-layer security, wiretap code design, post-quantum cryptography, error-control coding, author identification, and sports analytics.

This event is open to the public and registration is encouraged. 

 

 

This program is presented in collaboration with Northeastern’s Office of City & Community Engagement and the Boston Public Art Triennial.

title: Undergraduate Case Competition on Emerging Markets
description:
Following the success of last year's inaugural event, the Center for Emerging Markets (CEM) is excited to announce our second annual Undergraduate Case Competition on Emerging Markets on Saturday, October 18th, 2025.

 

This student-led competition will once again challenge Northeastern students to step beyond their coursework and tackle complex real-world business scenarios. Selected teams will have two days to analyze a case study focused on emerging markets, developing comprehensive strategies and solutions that address market dynamics, cultural considerations, and strategic implementation. They will then present to a distinguished panel of seasoned executives and industry leaders on the competition date. Winning teams from three initial rounds will advance to a final afternoon round.

 

CEM's undergraduate case competition welcomes multidisciplinary teams, encouraging collaboration between students from all Northeastern colleges and schools. Students may organize themselves and apply as a four-person team, or apply as individuals to be matched with a team. This diversity of academic backgrounds consistently produces innovative approaches and unique insights that mirror the collaborative nature of global business.

 

The competition offers substantial cash prizes up to $1,500 and an opportunity for students to present their strategic thinking to senior business leaders, gain real-world consulting experience, and build networks within the global business community.

title: Community Cyanotype Workshop with Gallery 360
description:
Join Northeastern's Gallery 360 for an artist workshop with Hannah Perrine Mode, an artist, educator, and researcher working at the intersections of art and environmental science. Working primarily between her native New England and her adopted homes in Alaska, Mode incorporates place-based making and cross-disciplinary exchange to deepen human connection to Earth systems and foster intersectional approaches to climate justice.

 

Mode will lead participants through a hands-on workshop to explore how scientific study and expression can foster care, curiosity, and community. Together, they will be guided by a central question: What can creative practices, close looking, and co-production teach us about caring for our environment, honoring the land and its histories (both human and ecologic), cultivating community care, and working towards social and environmental justice?

 

For the workshop, participants will create their own cyanotype prints using cuttings from the local landscape. After learning about Anna Atkins –  a 19th century cyanotype pioneer and botanist – the cyanotype process, and viewing Mode’s original cyanotype prints with plant cuttings and photo negatives, participants will collect materials from their surroundings and use them to create sun prints. They will print images of their cuttings to create abstract cyanotype prints to take home with them that act as records of their place, time, and human interaction with their environments. 

 

This workshop is open to the public and presented in collaboration between Gallery 360 and City & Community Engagement.

 

Registration is required as space is limited.

title: Faculty Works- In- Progress Series: Ellen Cushman
description: Professor Cushman explores the way that stories are the foundation for Indigenous lifeways since time immemorial — as nourishing as land, as necessary as air, as warming as fire, and as sustaining as water. Stories bring together the aesthetic details of life and living within the larger scale of collective work— gathering, persisting, creating knowledge, and documenting history.

title: Strategies for AI Use in Large Format Courses
description:
In this workshop you will explore strategies for navigating AI use in large-format courses to address your goals for student learning. Depending on your goals for learning in a specific assignment or activity, you may want to design the learning experience to be specifically AI-free (no AI tools), AI-assisted (bounded AI support), or AI-integrated (embedded use of AI tools) in a way that specifically builds AI literacies. You will consider specific practices for each category, exploring how transparent and strategic AI-integration can enhance student engagement and success while addressing authentic learning challenges inherent to large format courses.

 

This session is only open to Northeastern University students, staff and educators. Please use your Northeastern email when registering.

Accommodations

 

CATLR is committed to providing universal access to all of our events. For accommodations (e.g., sign language interpreters, alternative formats), please contact CATLR (catlr@northeastern.edu; +1-617-373-3157) as soon as possible. Advance notice is necessary to arrange for some accessibility needs.

Sessions are structured and facilitated by GLS Specialists who have selected and researched the topic of the week.

 

Join us by registering here!

title: Narratives of Trauma and Healing
description:
Award-winning Israeli novelist and clinical psychologist Ayelet Gundar-Goshen will discuss the impact of trauma in her literary work and the power of storytelling in her therapeutic work. In her new novel, The Wolf Hunt, the lives of an Israeli family based in the Silicon Valley are shattered after a terror attack on a local synagogue. The novel is an exploration of the fault lines in a community, a school, and a family, as an Israeli mother begins to suspect her teenage son of committing a terrible hate crime as revenge.

 

Working with terror victims in Israel after October 7, Ayelet Gundar-Goshen discovered that the same tools used by writers to create imaginary stories could be useful for people trying to survive a horrific, unimaginable reality. By turning a chaotic reality into a well-constructed story, by telling the story from beginning to end, the victims of trauma can create meaning and begin to heal.

title: AI Skills for the Workplace
description:
The AI revolution isn’t coming—it’s here. While others struggle to keep up, you can lead the way with practical AI skills that make you indispensable in today’s workplace. 

This focused training cuts through the hype to deliver the core AI competencies that drive real results: prompt engineering for better outputs, educational use cases, and real Northeastern University examples.

title: Fall Digital Scholarship Celebration
description:
Please join the Digital Scholarship Group, the Centers for Digital Scholarship, and the NULab for Digital Humanities and Computational Social Science for our annual fall scholarship celebration on October 22, 1–4pm Boston (hybrid + in-person), 10–11:15am Oakland (virtual), and 6–7:15pm London (virtual). 

 

This event is free and open to the public, but registration is required. For more information and to RSVP, see the event program. 

 

This year's event will begin in 350 Snell Library with hybrid lightning talks, with support for remote participation via Zoom. The lightning talks will feature researchers and projects from across the Northeastern community including CSSH, NULab, Northeastern University Oakland, CAMD, and the Northeastern University Library. Come learn about the diverse array of digital scholarship happening at NU from Isaac Fellman, Claire Lavarreda, Joel Lee, Candace Hazlett, Seo Eun "Sunny" Yang, and Meg Heckman.

 

Following the talks, there will be an in-person fair in the Centers for Digital Scholarship in which participants will have a chance to tour the CDS to meet with the projects and organizations in these spaces. Each project will include a "booth" with opportunities to meet with project staff, engage with the projects through activities, ask questions, and learn more about what is coming up for 2025–2026.  Booths will include: the Digital Scholarship Group, the Centers for Digital Scholarship, the NULab for Digital Humanities and Computational Social Science, the Women Writers Project, the Boston Research Center, the Center for Transformative Media, the Reckonings Project, the Digital Archive of Indigenous Language Persistence, the Early Black Boston Digital Almanac, the Early Caribbean Digital Archive, and the Digital Transgender Archive.

title: Summit: Family Business in India
description:
The Center for Emerging Markets at Northeastern University is proud to present its fourth annual India Summit: Family Business in India, as part of the Vivek and Vandana Sharma India Initiative. Building on previous summits that explored innovation, startups, and sustainability, this year's focus turns to Family Business in India and other emerging markets.

 

Recognizing the central role family enterprises play across emerging economies, the summit will bring together a diverse group of voices, including Indian family business leaders, academic experts in the field, young alumni representing next-generation leadership, overseas Indians managing family enterprises in Asia and the Middle East, and select family business leaders from other emerging markets. This gathering will provide a unique opportunity to examine the similarities and differences in family business dynamics across emerging economies, offering insights into one of the most significant drivers of economic growth in these regions.

 

REGISTRATION REQUIRED: 

Vivek and Vandana Sharma India Summit: Family Business in India - October 27, 2025

 

About the Vivek and Vandana Sharma India Initiative

CEM's 2025 India Summit is part of the Vivek and Vandana Sharma India Initiative, an endowed initiative at the Center for Emerging Markets with an aim to expand and deepen engagement with economic and business issues in India. It supports CEM's India Lecture series; enables scholars, students, and practitioners from India to complete visiting terms at the CEM; encourages D'Amore-McKim and CEM faculty to conduct use-inspired research in India; and creates a community of business leaders in the U.S. and India with a special interest in American-Indian economic ties.

See more of our programming about India 

Center for Emerging Markets Events

View all Center for Emerging Markets events

title: Webinar: On the Marginalisation of Women in Philosophy and Science
description:
Athene Donald, Francesca Peacock & Jennifer Park in conversation with Peter West

This event will focus on the historical marginalisation of women and women's writing in philosophy and science. Three experts in women's writing in philosophy and science - both past and present - will discuss how and why women were marginalised and excluded from these disciplines, challenges and obstacles faced by those taking on the task of recovering women's work, and the vital importance of developing historical narratives centering on women. For more information and to RSVP, see the event page.

 

Athene Donald is Emerita Professor of Physics at the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge and author of Not Just For the Boys: Why We Need More Women in Science published by Oxford University Press in 2023.

 

Francesca Peacock is the author of a recent biography of the 17th Century polymath Margaret Cavendish, Pure Wit: The Revolutionary Life of Margaret Cavendish published by Head of Zeus in 2023 (UK) and Pegasus book in 2024 (US).

 

Jennifer Park is Lecturer in Early Modern English at Glasgow University and a specialist in early modern literature and critical race theory.

 

Peter West is an Assistant Professor of Philosophy at Northeastern University London working in Early Modern Philosophy and Early Analytic Philosophy.

title: Data Destruction Day
description:
Have you upgraded to a new phone or laptop? Did you know that a factory reset doesn’t completely wipe your old data? If a device contains any data or files, you need to destroy it in a safe and secure manner so that no one can access your old information and use it for malicious purposes. But how?
 

The annual Data Destruction Day is back! This event will be hosted on the Boston campus on Tuesday, Oct. 28, 2025. At this event, students, faculty, and staff are invited to bring anything that holds data, including personal devices and paper materials, for safe and secure physical destruction.
 

Yes, that old laptop, smartphone, printer, or smart speaker is eligible! Simply bring your devices and paper files to the event and on-site staff will take care of the rest. This event ensures that your data cannot be recovered from old devices. As an added bonus, this is also an environmentally sustainable way to dispose of electronics!

This event is hosted as part of Northeastern's 2025 Cybersecurity Awareness Month plans.

title: Outlook Unleashed: AI Tools for Email Excellence
description: Transform your email experience with powerful AI capabilities in Microsoft Outlook. This training introduces you to innovative tools that streamline communication, enhance productivity, and help you manage your inbox more effectively. You’ll learn to leverage AI features for smart composing, intelligent summarization, and priority management. Whether you’re managing a busy professional inbox or looking to save time on everyday email tasks, this session provides practical techniques to elevate your Outlook skills from functional to exceptional. Discover how AI-powered tools can help you communicate more efficiently while maintaining a personal touch in your correspondence.

title: Husky How-To: Everyday Practices for Stress and Resilience
description: Join Nicole Fiore BHS’02, MS’03 as she shares her journey from early lessons in self-empowerment to discovering timeless practices for managing stress and anxiety. Drawing on insights from teachers like Tony Robbins and Viktor Frankl, Nicole will show how we can create space between anxiety and response. This interactive session will include a live tapping demonstration, simple grounding practices, and accessible self-care strategies that don’t require expensive treatments. Learn how to set the tone for your day, reduce stress naturally, and explore vision boards as a tool for manifesting positive change. Walk away with practical, empowering techniques to support your mental and emotional well-being.

title: Writing Creatively in the Age of AI with Vauhini Vara
description:
Award-winning novelist and tech journalist Vauhini Vara reads from her new book Searches, followed by a conversation with Professor Stephanie Young, head of the new Creative Writing minor for Mills College.

 

In 2021, Vara published “Ghosts,” an essay about her sister’s death written in collaboration with AI. The piece went viral, establishing Vara as a leading voice in debates on creativity and emerging technologies. Her 2025 book Searches blends memoir, journalism, and the raw material of internet culture. Vara suggests that by harnessing the collective creativity that defines us, we might imagine a freer, more empowered relationship with our machines—and with one another.

 

All are welcome to attend this free online event. Students interested in the Mills College Creative Writing minor and/or currently enrolled in Mills College Creative Writing classes are especially welcome!

title: AI and the Global Music Industry
description:
Evolution is the process of growth and transformation, moving from simplicity to complexity—a concept that is clearly visible in the global music industry. From how music is produced to how it is consumed, the industry continually adapts to maintain engagement and profitability on a global scale. Join GLS as we explore the innovative ways the music industry is evolving, particularly through the use of AI tools to enhance the consumer experience and drive business success. This session will examine these trends through a STEAM lens, offering insights into the intersection of technology, creativity, and industry strategy.

 

Register here.

title: Book Talk with Amy S. Kaufman
description:
What if everything we believed about Robin Hood was a lie? 

 

In The Traitor of Sherwood Forest, medieval scholar Amy S. Kaufman reimagines the oldest version of Robin Hood, the chaotic trickster found in the original ballads. Told through the eyes of one of Robin’s spies, a peasant girl named Jane, Kaufman’s novel explores voices rarely centered in historical fiction and weaves conversations about class, gender, the romanticization of war, and the dangerous allure of extremism into a deeply atmospheric, racing story. 

 

Join the author for a conversation about how the medieval Robin Hood legend differs from our modern stories, the challenge of exploring the complicated roots of a beloved character, and what we can learn from morally gray heroes in the modern world. 

 

**This event is open to Northeastern community members only.

title: Hear & Now
description:
Join Global Learner Support and Wellness for our monthly virtual gatherings, Hear & Now, a dedicated space for the NU community to connect, reflect, and process. These gatherings provide an opportunity to share what’s going on in your life while engaging in meaningful conversations with peers.

 

Hear & Now is a safe and supportive environment where you can co-regulate, find comfort, and receive encouragement from GLS, Wellness, and your fellow community members. Whether you're seeking to share your experiences, gain insight, or simply listen, this space is here to help you navigate life’s challenges together. Register

title: East Bay Art Yesterday: 100 Years of Bay Area Photography & Ceramics
description:
Join us for a discussion that reflects upon the history of photography and ceramics in the Bay Area, MCAM’s role within that history, and where Bay Area art is headed in the future.

 

Moderated by Liam O’Donoghue, local journalist and host of the podcast East Bay Yesterday, the conversation will feature MCAM Director Stephanie Hanor, Erik Scollon, Associate Professor and Head of Ceramics at California College of the Arts, and Shana Lopes, Assistant Curator of Photography at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. 

 

The quartet will discuss Bay Area artists’ roles in transforming both photography and ceramics into respected fine art forms; the artists, professors, and museum directors who have passed through this campus and shaped the Art Museum’s collection; and the artistic innovation that happened both on campus and in the wider Bay Area.
